Calculator

Class CalculatorValue

  • java.lang.Object
    • Calculator.CalculatorValue

  • public class CalculatorValue
extends java.lang.Object

    Title: CalculatorValue Class.

    Description: A component of a JavaFX demonstration application that performs computations

    Copyright: Lynn Robert Carter Â© 2019

    Version:
    4.00 2018-01-24 Long integer implementation of the CalculatorValue class, 4.01 2018-01-29 Added the sub, mpy and div method which perform the required computations., 4.02 2019-02-19 Aman added the log method to calculate the log base 2 Jatin tested the methods so that it properly works., 4.03 2019-03-20 Aman added the FSM code Jatin added the functioning of FSM and declared all the variables needed to run the FSM, 4.04 2019-04-06 Added the algorithm for the Addition, subtraction, multiplication and division for the error term Added the new attributes to accept error term, changed the constructor to accept the error term, 4.05 2019-09-29 Made the changes in the add, sub, mpy, div and sqrt methods so that they do the calculation with UNumber, 4.06 2019-11-24 Made the changes in the add, sub, mpy, div and sqrt methods so that they do the calculations with Units, 4.07 2020-03-12 Made some changes in the existing methods to make it compatible with definitions and TableView
    Author:
    Lynn Robert Carter (Baseline), Jatin Thakur

      • CalculatorValue

        public CalculatorValue()
        This is the default constructor

      • CalculatorValue

        public CalculatorValue(double v,
                       double e)
        This constructor creates a calculator value based on a double. For future calculators, it is best to avoid using this constructor.

      • CalculatorValue

        public CalculatorValue(CalculatorValue v)
        This copy constructor creates a duplicate of an already existing calculator value

      • CalculatorValue

        public CalculatorValue(java.lang.String s,
                       java.lang.String e)
        This constructor creates a calculator value from a string... Due to the nature of the input, there is a high probability that the input has errors, so the routine returns the value with the error message value set to empty or the string of an error message.

      • checkMeasureValue

        public static java.lang.String checkMeasureValue(java.lang.String input)
        This method is a mechanical transformation of a Finite State Machine diagram into a Java method.
        Parameters:
        input - The input string for the Finite State Machine
        Returns:
        An output string that is empty if every things is okay or it will be a string with a help description of the error follow by two lines that shows the input line follow by a line with an up arrow at the point where the error was found.

      • checkErrorTerm

        public static java.lang.String checkErrorTerm(java.lang.String input)
        This method is a mechanical transformation of a Finite State Machine diagram into a Java method.
        Parameters:
        input - The input string for the Finite State Machine
        Returns:
        An output string that is empty if every things is okay or it will be a string with a help description of the error follow by two lines that shows the input line follow by a line with an up arrow at the point where the error was found.

      • add

        public void add(CalculatorValue v)
        The following methods implement computation on the calculator values with error term having values as UNumber. These routines assume that the caller has verified that things are okay for the operation to take place. These methods understand the technical details of the values and their reputations, hiding those details from the business logic and user interface modules. Since this is addition and we do not yet support units, we don't recognize any errors.

      • sub

        public void sub(CalculatorValue v)
        The below is the subtraction which subtracts the value with error term having values as UNumber and round off the error term to one significant digit.

        v -
